newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Stocks to Watch Today - Aug 18.
newsitem.headline: Australian Stocks to Watch Today - Aug 18.

text.p: Some Australian stocks to watch this morning:
Aristocrat Leisure is expected to report annual results later this morning, with analysts forecasts focusing on a pre-abnormal net profit of around A$33 million.

Bendigo Bank is expected to report its annual results later on Monday. Bendigo said in late June it expected pre-tax earnings in 1996/97 would be about 20 percent down on 1995/96's A$22.09 million because of sharp competition for housing finance.
Lend Lease Corp forecast on Sunday its project management and funds management units would post 40 percent higher revenues in the current year to June 30, 1998.
Construction group Leighton Holdings Ltd ruled out on Sunday using its cash pile of over A$400 million to buy out the 44.9 percent stake in Leighton held by German construction group Hochtief AG.

Australian gold miner Sons of Gwalia Ltd signalled on Friday it would no longer tolerate underperforming properties and would close at least three mines by early next year and review others. The company's Golden Pig and Frasers underground mines at the Southern Cross deposit will close immediately, while the Copperhead mine at Bullfinch is to close in about six or seven months, Gwalia executive chairman and managing director Peter Lalor told Reuters.

New Zealand's Brierley Investments Ltd said on Friday it will vigorously defend proceedings brought by Australia's corporate watchdog over trading in the shares of newspaper publisher John Fairfax Holdings Ltd. Earlier on Friday, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) said it applied to the Corporations and Securities Panel for a declaration that trading in Fairfax shares by Merrill Lynch and Brierley was unacceptable conduct.

BSkyB Plc chief executive Sam Chisholm gave a ringing endorsement to his successor on Friday while the company said the move into digital television would put a brake on profit growth. The dominant force in British pay TV, BSkyB reported a 22 percent rise in pre-tax profit to 314 million pounds ($499 million) in the year to June 30. BSkyB shares fell 34.5p to 435.5p. Analysts said the profit figure fell a little short of expectations when one-off items were stripped out and cited uncertainties over the cost of going digital.
